doc.field: Dept of Music, Canadian Centre for Ethnomusicology

The Aswan Music Project (Egypt) aims to harness tremendous power of music and arts education to mobilise and connect communities, seeking stronger social integration and pluralism while celebrating richness and diversity of Aswan’s cultural heritage, with a focus on Indigenous Nubian communities.
Singing and Dancing for Health (Ghana) aims to create, evaluate, and refine effective music and dance interventions for public health education and promotion among Indigenous Dagbamba communities
Kinka (Ghana) aims to foster community cohesion among Indigenous Ewe communities, using music.
Music for Maternal, Neonatal and Child Health (Ethiopia) focuses on health education in Indigenous Amhara and Oromo communities, through radio and music.
all projects are participatory action research oriented, meaning they are co-guided by communities.

In the NZ colonial archives I uncovered an unknown, handwritten journal, in te reo Māori, by Eruera Karaka Te Ngara. While working for the Melanesian Mission, Te Ngara explored a range of southwest Pacific islands in 1862, recording his experiences. He went on to teach at the mission school, eventually being ordained as an Anglican priest. My recent SSHRC grant is funding the translation (with NZ collaborators), editing, and publication of his remarkable journal.

I've been reaching out to descendants, to let them know of the journal's existence, and its current location in the archives of a public library. I've also been explaining my project and its approval by the required Indigenous authorities, in order to reassure them and to invite their collaboration. On a research trip this summer I hope to meet with community members, if they're willing, to see if they might be willing to share memories of their ancestor. The public library will be sharing the journal's transliteration and translation, and the full publication will be on an open access platform so that community members will have easy access to it. I should also mention that my translation collaborators are both Māori.

tapahtêyimôkamik: Co-designing, piloting, and evaluating inclusive rites of passage for Indigenous gender and sexuality-diverse youth; identifying roles, responsibilities and skills to restore balance and self-determination of ayisiniw ota asiskiy (a human being of this earth) and strengthen interpersonal relations for the youth with their wellbeing, kinship, and the land.
The Centering Indigenous Women’s Wellness Governance in the Academy project explores wellbeing grounded in Indigenous women's decolonial love theory, philosophy and creative practices.
Dept of Drama, Faculty of Arts
Board Member - Solid State Community Industries and PuSh International Performing Arts Festival
(Baniwa) Itacoatiara-Mirim Community in the Amazonian peri-urban area of São Gabriel da Cachoeira
(Musqueam & Squamish) Coast Salish territories - Lower Mainland area of BC
protection and maintenance of land and water relations

1. Hemispheric Encounters Ecologies research (Spatial Ecologies research in Brazilian settings) 2. Area specialist - Vancouver Parks Board Colonial Audit project 3. Historical research - 1940s & 50s - Indian Act revision and performance
1. Community-led research projects in Brazilian contexts 2. Colonial Audit implemented by Parks Board councillor as part of UNDRIP implementation 3. researcher initiated
It depends on the project - but I am available to support with scholarly, archival research and writing projects

Cultural adaptation of a child health resource to meet the information needs and preferences of Metis parents in Manitoba
This project arose from a need identified by the MMF for Metis families to have access to meaningful and appropriate resources when seeking emergency care for their children.
Research Aims: This project will adapt an existing child health resource to meet the identified experiences, needs and preferences of Metis parents looking for health information when their child is acutely ill.
Methods: This research will employ a multi-stage, multi-methods design including discussion groups, community advisory committee, scoping review and qualitative methods.
Significance: This project is an important step in addressing an identified need by the Metis community for families to have culturally relevant and meaningful resources available for when their children are acutely ill, and in the pursuit of equitable care for all children in Canada.
Supervisor to the PhD student (Lisa Knisley, Faculty of Nursing); co-director of the healthcare organization that the MMF reached out to requesting this research

1) First Nations Childhood Immunization (FINCH) Project: Partnership project with Maskwacis Health Services to identify and address barriers to vaccine access for children in the Maskwacis community. 2) Nishtoohtamihk la michinn avik aen nijhwii (understanding vaccination): Partnership project with the Metis Nation of Alberta to understand immunization coverage and experiences among Métis people in Alberta
Members of the community health services are partners on each project

Major projects are and have been focused on Indigenous community-led Indigenous law revitalization, in a range of subjects, including child and family wellbeing, membership and citizenship, governance, MMIWGQ2+, wills and estates, etc.

Communities initiate research projects and we develop a Research Partnership Agreement. For each major research project, there is at least one community-based researcher who takes the same training as the university based research assistants, is paid the same or more, to coordinate and collaborate on the research plan. Workshops and training are open to community members and many attend. A crucial part of every research project is community interviews and focus groups, and research outcomes are brought back to community members to review, validate and/or correct, prior to finalization.
Dept. of Strategy, Entrepreneurship, and Management; Faculty of Business
Int'l Research Fellow, Oxford University Centre for Corporate Reputation
Saskatoon, but people are distributed widely

I have been investigating the extent to which business schools in Canada are indigenizing and decolonizing their people, practices, and processes. I am especially curious about curricular change and how it came about.
Everyone is talking about it, so I decided to start looking.
Kelly Lendsay, founder of Luminary, contributes to project design and mobilizes respondents.
Faculty of Arts, Department of Economics
Center for Indian Country Development, Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis

I'll highlight 2 projects: (1) "Drained Away" focuses on the inequitable production of oil on/near First Nations lands. (2) "Native CDFIs" is a research agenda that focuses on the role of Native Community Development Financial Institutions in Indian Country. We study several facets of this, including: Native CDFI holistic lending practices, Native CDFI financial training, and opportunities and barriers in the industry.
Project (1) was initiated by researchers: myself and my coauthor. Project (2) was initiated by a combination of researchers, leaders in the industry, and the Center for Indian Country Development

Project (1) has been pursued in close collaboration with Indigenous guides, including an Indigenous-owned consulting firm, an Elder, and another expert in the oil and gas industry with intimate knowledge of the IOGC. We have also regularly engaged with the Indian Resource Council. And we recently forged relationships with several chiefs of Treaty 6. For Project (2): researchers have relied on close engagement with leaders of Native CDFIs from the start of the research project. CDFIs have shared their data and, in exchange, we (researchers) return individualized reports to participants. We have also interviewed approximately 50 Native CDFIs in order to ensure we are conducting research that will produce benefits for CDFIs themselves. We have helped CDFIs develop proprietary risk assessment measures, and we plan to co-author with one of our Native CDFI partners for a planned research paper.

Currently working on a few projects with the Métis Nation of Alberta - My PhD research related to HPV related cancer prevention in Métis families in Alberta, as well as a childhood immunization project with the MNA exploring vaccination coverage in the Nation. With the Métis Nation of Ontario I am a co-Investigator on a couple of projects exploring Métis covid response in Ontario, as well as a project exploring sexually transmitted and blood-borne infections in the citizenship.

Projects with the Métis Nation of Alberta emerged from conversations between myself and the health director, as well as many Métis families I know. Our work in Ontario came from identified questions from the Nation there.

There are community members involved in all stages of my PhD research through the keeoukaywin methodology. In the other projects, there are varying degrees of community involvement dependent on the methods and approaches used.
Different parts of Canada with a focus on rural, remote, Northern regions

DigitalNWT works with Northern communities and organizations to design and deliver free courses about digital technologies in the NWT.
First Mile Connectivity Consortium (FMCC) is a national non-profit association of First Nations community-based telecommunications organizations serving remote and rural communities. FMCC is primarily engaged in developing evidence-based policy related to broadband infrastructure, digital services and technology adoption in remote and rural communities.
Connecting Indigenous Families in the Northwest Territories aims to address the current digital gap faced by Indigenous families in rural/remote NWT communities. UAlberta will conduct a longitudinal (2023-2026) study of technology access, adoption and use of connectivity by participating households.
Piikani Nation Secondary School, Elders, youth and university-based researchers co-designed an annual summer camp program grounded in Blackfoot (Piikani) approaches to digital literacy.

DigitalNWT - researcher in collaboration w/ NWT groups; FMCC - First Nations technology organizations; Connecting Indigenous Families - Native Women's Association of NWT / Smart Communities Society NWT; Piikani Digital Literacy - Research and community Elder

Governance / Steering Committee, research design, planning, implementation (data collection and analysis), writing/authorship, presenting results and knowledge mobilization (policy, curriculum, digital resources, etc)
Faculty of Native Studies, U of Alberta

In partnership with the Kugaaruk Elders Research Advisory Committee, “Introducing the emotional and affective geographies of law: strengthening community through the practice and feeling(s) of Inuit law” began in 2014. Based on interviews, focus groups, and observations at Elder-led land camps on fishing and sealing, this SSHRCC-funded project investigates the intersections of Inuit pidquhiit (a form of law) and emotions in respect of three important community events: the counselling provided by the men’s group, consultations held for the development of a mine, and the historical proposal to relocate the community. Where Inuit law helps to mend relationships, manage resources, and inform self-determination, the reason/emotion binary is unsettled and the vibrant role of the land(nuna)/sea/ice and nonhumans in Inuit emotional geographies is illuminated.

Elders Research Advisory Committee - project planning, provide advice and understanding, led Elder-youth land camps, co-authors, conference co-presenters. All community members/participants: verification of transcripts, feedback on interpretations, review of drafts, contributions to community report and three maps (for the school) documenting, e.g., hunting and lifestyles, artwork for publications.

My main research involves working with collaborators in the Inuvialuit Settlement Region on development of their digital library of cultural heritage resources. Our focus is on community-driven knowleedge organization and resource description in service of language and culture sharing and creation.
Staff members at the Inuvialuit Cultural Resource Centre
Staff at the Inuvialuit Cultural Resource Centre and members of the community are project collaborators. The project is very much community driven in all ways
Obstetrics and Gynecology, University of Alberta
WCHRI and Division of Reproductive Sciences

Our research has been carried out in Maskwacis. The main topics have been as follows: Indigenous Women's Health and Wellness and Aging Well, Gender and Wellness, Menopause Research. The research assistant is from the community and lives there. We work with an Elders Advisory Committee consisting of Maskwacis women Elders who ensure that any research activity is for the benefit of the community.

They are vital in all stages of the research from initiating the research idea, through design and conduct, to reporting of the findings - community members contribute at all stages - as researchers, participants, writers, editors, presenters at local and scientific meetings and locally at MCC and different types of community events

Under the supervision of Dr. Laurel Wheeler, a Phd. Economist, my job was to help aggregate data to research the Distribution of Pollution in Western Canada, this projected was completed in August 2021. My most recent job was transcribing interviews to help native CDFI's in the USA identify barriers and gain more access to funding, this job was started in May 2022 and completed in August 2022.
Community members are a vital source of information that helps forums the data to personal experiences
Young Indigenous Women's Circle of Leadership, under Supporting Indigenous Language Revitalization and Elementary Education

Working for the Young Indigenous Women’s Circle of Leadership (YIWCL) as a Research Assistant, Program Coordinator and Instructor, I’ve had the opportunity to plan and to assist instructors in putting together workshops and events for youth girls, post secondary ladies and their families. Each of our events had the overall goals of sharing our combined knowledge of Cree language and culture to aid in language revitalization, as well as helping to build and help heal young ladies’ self esteem and pride in their Indigenous heritage. The events are often centered around the Arts (music, dance, traditional crafting) to provide an opportunity for all to engage in participatory learning. Legitimate participation, mentor/apprenticeship and storytelling are part of our Indigenous teaching methodologies, and we each incorporate our professional skills as Teachers/Educators as well. I have also done Cree-English Transcription (SRO and Syllabics) for this and previous projects.
Education Faculty and the Researcher, for the most part, but some events were planned and carried out in communities by instructors from those areas.
Elders, Participants, Instructors, Planners and Hosts, Professional services (eg. Artists, Caterers, Bussing, Space Rental)
Manitoba, where the Red River meets Lake Winnipeg
living the cosmology of the Land

Doctoral dissertation. how to design local climate change adaptations in the pluriverse based on Indigenous conditions for cultural continuity: relating with Land and Kin, living the cosmology of the Land, regenerating, sharing, welcoming difference, reMembering cultural memories.
COVID19 required me to switch to a theoretical dissertation. My project does not involve human subjects.
Centre for Mathematics, Science and Technology Education
Centre for Mathematics, Science and Technology Education

The educational system in Alberta (and across Canada) has been called to integrate Indigenous knowledges and teaching approaches in their classroom by the Truth and Reconciliation Commission. Many Alberta teachers have shown interest and willingness to participate and become allies with Indigenous Peoples to achieve this goal. However
in our experience as an educational research and outreach centre
they feel they lack the ability to do this due to inexperience with pedagogical methods

the process of decolonization in general and the unique holistic environmental approaches of Indigenous Peoples. In partnership with a locally-based Indigenous Knowledge-keeper CMASTE has offered a year long Land- based Learning experience for kindergarten to grade 12 science teachers. The purpose of this study is to assess how Land-based Learning could be used as an effective teacher professional development model with a sample of science teachers in Alberta.

The educational system in Alberta has been called to integrate Indigenous knowledge and teaching approaches in their classroom by the Truth and Reconciliation Commission. Many Alberta teachers have shown interest and willingness to participate and become allies with Indigenous Peoples to achieve this goal. However, in our experience as an educational research and outreach centre, teachers often find that, especially in the sciences, they feel they lack the ability to do this due to inexperience with pedagogical methods, the process of decolonization in general and the unique holistic environmental approaches of Indigenous Peoples. In partnership with a locally-based Indigenous Knowledge-keeper CMASTE has offered a year long Land- based Learning experience for kindergarten to grade 12 science teachers. The purpose of this study is to assess how Land-based Learning could be used as an effective teacher professional development model with a sample of science teachers in Alberta.
Art and Design/ Faculty of Native Studies
I don't understand or I have concerns.
I do not consent to my information being in the database.

This research seeks to expand our understanding of community housing led by Indigenous organizations by identifying what Indigenous-led community housing organizations need from housing policy in order to serve Indigenous peoples successfully.
Using an Indigenist research paradigm, this project centres Indigenous ways of knowing, being, and doing, and is built upon a framework of decolonization and relational accountability. Specific methods include decolonial participatory action research and OCAP (ownership, control, access, and possession) by the Indigenous communities engaged in the research.
In a community-led, relationship-focused approach, workshops will be held with Indigenous-led community housing organizations in Alberta, Canada. The researcher and the community will co-develop a vision and strategy that leads to greater access to housing for Indigenous peoples, and ultimately, decolonization.
Part of a national project on community housing
Transcription and Translation of Colonial Nahuatl Documents

I am currently co-editing a volume on "Indigenous Peoples in/and Video Games" and writing a paper on the representation of "Aztec" women in Mexican Indie video games. I am also conducting an archival study tracing the production and re-productions of Mesoamerican (Aztec, Maya and Mixtec) and Mexican colonial codices (Indigenous pictorial manuscripts) from their early hand-made reproductions, chromolithographs, facsimiles etc. up to their more recent digitized forms. I also regularly participate online in the transcription and translation of colonial Nahuatl documents in collaboration with scholars around the world via Dr. John Sullivan's group at the University of Utah and have more recently collaborated in the NEH-AHRC funded Nahuatl Paleography and Digital Humanities Institute "Unlocking the Colonial Archive" at the University of Texas at Austin.

The researcher initiated the co-edited volume on Indigenous video games and colonial Mexican codices. The Nahuatl paleography institute was initated by researchers at the University of Texas at Austin.

It depends on the project. For example, in the co-edited volume on Indigenous peoples in/and video games I invited Indigenous video game scholars/practitioners to participate as co-editors and contributors. The research on codice reproduction work deals primarily with colonial archival research. The collaborative colonial Nahuatl transcription/translation institute has been collaborative with scholars worldwide and has meaningfully included the participation of Native Nahua speakers.
High Level, Hay River, Fort Simpson
We monitor water quality in the Hay River watershed and in the Dehcho region. We also monitor peatland greenhouse gas emissions.
I don't understand or I have concerns.
I do not consent to my information being in the database.

Recent research from our group has naturally converged with traditional knowledge and show how fish interact with their environment to promote health. We have documented and offer quantifiable outputs for discrete interactions between fish and their environment that are central to fighting pathogens, controlling inflammation, and restoring wounds. We believe that this offers one opportunity to stimulate new conversations and enhance connectivity between the University of Alberta and Indigenous communities.
intersections of Native and African identity in cultural formations in U.S. Indian Country

My current project recovers the stories of Muscgoee holders of land allotments in the context of rise of a hydrocarbon society of pipelines, highways, and oil and gas leases. I work with a variety of stakeholders (descendants of allottees, the Muscogee Nation, archives at museums and universities) to reveal the machinations of the wealth transfer from Muscogee citizens to the petroleum industry.
I initiated it while working with a Muscogee citizen research partner on a related project.
Muscogee citizen are ultimately the ones who decide which stories of allottees are presented in a public-facing manner. I do most of the archival research and story scaffolding.
We are examining the habitat and ecology of the Ronald Lake bison herd north of Fort McKay.
Funding (Mitacs) and support of field research

I work with Métis Crossing to deliver a community service learning project to my fourth-year Native Studies seminar students. We develop several interpretive experiences for the Crossing aimed at teaching visitors about Métis history, governance, and culture. Students complete a research report for Métis Crossing on an assigned topic, then develop a fun and accessible activity that can be used to teach the knowledge to visitors at the site. I also co-deliver a on-the-land camp with Chief Julius School in Fort McPherson, NWT aimed at connecting Teetł'it Gwich'in students with elders and traditional knowledge. Leading a team of university researchers, we provide high school students with a land-based university course alongside their Gwich'in high school curriculum, allowing them to earn high school and university credit. Students receive an on-the-land experience, taught by their elders as well as university instruction in Indigenous studies, climate history, and dendrochronology.
Collaboratively, with friends from the community organization.
co-leads, I like to work in collaborative relationships

I currently am partnered with the Athabasca Chipewyan First Nation studying the foraging ecology and landscape of the Ronald Lake Wood Bison herd in northeastern Alberta. With sustainable management as a goal, I study how the herd interacts with wetlands within their range. First, I study the variance in environmental conditions between wetlands and how these differences influence the quantity and proportion of bison selected forage items. Second, I study how bison select winter foraging locations while balancing the energy demands of winter conditions. Third, I am observing the vegetative regeneration of bison diet items while controlling for different intensities of grazing activity. Finally, I am studying the temporal foraging patterns of the herd and assessing the degree of site fidelity to individual forage patches.
Community members are present on the land in which my research takes place. We talk to them about historic trends and current advice on navigating the area.
Close to Edmonton, and then south, near Lethbridge

We have been developing a telehealth platform over the past 4 years to provide better access to rural Albertans to more specialized healthcare services. Now that the platform is becoming embedded into AHS operations, we believe it is an appropriate time to present the system to Indigenous communities and see how it can help provide better access to care for rural Indigenous people, particularly those living on reservations. We are still in the connection/relationship building stage and are appreciative of any advice and direction to help make sure our work is appropriate to the communities we aim to serve.
The Principal Investigator, Dr. Martin Ferguson-Pell
They help guide the services and delivery methods, but we have not identified community partners yet.

Gwendolyn's research interests are the mental health and wellbeing of Indigenous women, particularly in the areas of infertility, childlessness, caregiving, and sexual violence. Gwendolyn is also interested in historical/intergenerational trauma, multicultural counselling, Indigenous psychology, and cultural/traditional approaches to wellness.
Recent research projects: 1) Program Evaluation of an Indigenous Healing from Sexual Trauma Circle 2)Supporting Indigenous employees within non-Indigenous organizations 3)Indigenous-Focusing Oriented Therapy - Indigenous trauma-sensitive psychotherapy 4)Developing Indigenous Psychology course
A collaboration of researcher and community.
They are consulted every step of the way, ensuring the relevancy of the project.
I don't understand or I have concerns.
I do not consent to my information being in the database.
Faculty of Pharmacy & Pharmaceutical Sciences, University of Alberta

For pharmacists to be trusted health care providers to First Nation People, they must be able to build relationships with their First Nation patients. No researchers in Canada have studied First Nation People’s views on their relationships with community pharmacists. Alexander First Nation (AFN) community members will have conversations with an Inuvialuk researcher so that we can find out more about how people of AFN view medications in general, whether they trust pharmacists, and about some of their interactions in the past with pharmacists. We will be speaking with adults from the community and using a few guiding questions to facilitate these conversations. We will be analyzing the responses with members of the AFN through meetings with the Alexander Research Committee and using the resultant themes to inform the Alexander Health Director and the general Alexander community, as well as the pharmacy profession and other researchers.
co-design of the project, co-authors on papers, co-presenters at conferences, regular review/meetings regarding updates on the research
School of Civil and Environmental Engineering, University of Alberta
Improve the water quality by using reclamation materials

My lab will use both open access and traditional, local Indigenous ethnobotanical knowledge to identify local medicinal plants, foods or herbal products with known or presumptive therapeutic applications. I am actively collaborating with Dr. Roy Golsteyn who leads the Prairie-to-Pharmacy Program. This program brings traditional Indigenous knowledge to help identify useful prairie medicinal plants. We are using both targeted and untargeted metabolomic methods to isolated and identify active ingredients in ~450 prairie plant extracts prepared from 135 prairie plant species. Standard cell-based and organoid assays will be developed or acquired to assess the presumptive activities of these products or their extracts. This project adheres to OCAP principles and we are consulting with indigenous communities to further define the research parameters and develop the plans for knowledge co-creation, dissemination and attribution.
Knowledge providers, Knowledge seeking, traditional medicinal plant knowledge
Hydrologic model and prediction system development
Help define the demand and evaluation system of the flood/drought prediction system
Mostly in Alberta along with the Yukon and Nunavut

My two largest projects at the moment are (1) a Brain Canada Foundation-funded project in partnership with the Maskwacis Community and the Martin Family Initiative to evaluate the health, social, and educational outcomes associated with a community-led prenatal-to-preschool early intervention program (the Early Years program); and (2) a CIHR-funded project with the goal of developing culturally grounded tools and processes for understanding Indigenous children's mental health. I also have a SSHRC-funded project in partnership with the Edmonton Police Service to examine how police can work in culturally safe ways with structurally marginalized youth, including Indigenous youth. I am also working on a project in partnership with the Canada FASD Research Network to understand how Indigenous principles of healing from substance abuse interface with the principles of FASD-informed service provision.
All of my research projects are initiated by community partners.

All of my projects have significant community involvement. Depending on the capacity of community partners to commit time to research, projects typically involve community members in study design and formulation of research objectives, participant recruitment, data collection and analysis, as well as knowledge mobilization.

My research is focused on individuals with rare genetic disorders. Given the geographic distribution of Indigenous people, some of the disorders studied may impact other members of the community without knowing, so from one patient they may become a community issue. The information resulting from our basic and clinical research is meant to empower patients and families and better their experience in health care. We would like to engage collaboratively by developing a partnership with the affected communities and fellow Indigenous researchers.
Applied Conservation Ecology Lab - Renewable Resources

Free-ranging and free from bovine tuberculosis and brucellosis, the Ronald Lake wood bison population in northern Alberta has ecological, cultural, and spiritual importance. The ongoing sustainability of the population requires stewardship and management that aligns with the goals of Indigenous governments, provincial and federal governments, and other interested parties. Partnering with The Firelight Group, alongside Mikisew Cree First Nation and Athabasca Chipewyan First Nation, this project aims to estimate the Ronald Lake bison habitat supply based carrying capacity. Additional habitat changes scenarios may also be modelled to help predict future change to the herd. The overall goal is to support ongoing and future Ronald Lake bison management, stewardship, and governance decisions to ensure there are healthy and viable Ronald Lake bison for generations to come.
The Firelight Group / Graduate Student (connected to previous working relationship)

Aside from ongoing communication between the Applied Conservation Ecology Lab, The Firelight Group (an Indigenous owned research group), Athabasca Chipewyan First Nation Dene Lands and Resource Management, and Mikisew Cree First Nation Government and Industry Relations staff, the project will include in-community sessions and focus groups with knowledge holders.

My project works with the mentors of the “Indigenous Youth Mentorship Program.” IYMP is an after-school program where Indigenous high school students mentor elementary students on healthy living topics. It is known that mentorship experience in teen years leads to academic and career success in adulthood. My project’s goal is to understand how mentorship experience affects the mentors' relationships with education and career planning. Based on past work with the mentors, they will generate rich insights into the support they need for further academic and career success. The results of my research project will go on to guide the development of a national IYMP-specific high school course.
Dr. Kate Storey and the Indigenous Youth Mentorship Program
Department of Earth and Atmospheric Sciences

My current research project is in collaboration with Cynthia Puddu (McEwan University) and Niginan Housing. It focuses on the experiences of youth moving out of care into supported housing. We are also evaluating the impact of cultural programing in the housing experiences of youth and other residents.
This project was initiated by Niginan Housing Ventures.

Community members participate in a variety of ways. We have involved elders from the program in engagement with residents. We have also involved Niginan Housing Staff, all who are Indigenous, in the design and implementation of the research. Finally, we have involved youth through longitudinal interviewing.
School of Public Health, University of Alberta

My PhD research aims to explore the validity of preference-based health-related quality of life (HRQL) measures for Indigenous people. Preference-based measures (PBM) are surveys used to assess health-related quality of life of people or groups; they are used when considering health care approaches and inform decisions about health policies and spending. It is important that the PBMs can correctly and consistently assess health for a person or group. We have found that although PBM are being increasingly used to assess HRQL in Indigenous people, there is not much information on how well these surveys perform (validity, reliability) in this group. We plan to start by looking at the EQ-5D-5L, which is currently being used by health systems in Alberta to evaluate health, and how well it might (or might not) represent health for Indigenous people living in Alberta, and what might be good directions to pursue towards measuring health appropriately for Indigenous people.

Research team members include an Indigenous research assistant and an Elder. We are developing plans to share and listen to Urban Indigenous community, health and policy workers throughout the project.
